author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Should I Buy Shapewear?
description: A reader asks for the secret behind many celebrity silhouettes.
content: Welcome to the booming world of shapewear, a.k.a. the modern no-more-pain version of what used to be known as a girdle: stretchy undergarments that promise to suck in and hold up the parts you want sucked in and held up, polish your overall lines and otherwise create the illusion of a sculpted form.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Jackson
title: Britain on the Brink
description: The prime minister is in peril — but is the country in crisis too?
content: From “The Daily” newsletter: One big idea on the news, from the team that brings you “The Daily” podcast. You can sign up for the newsletter here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: The Nets Were to Be a Team of Destiny. But Not This Kind.
description: The collapse of the Nets’ superteam of Kevin Durant, James Harden and Kyrie Irving echoes the falls of other starry groupings. But they had a chance to be different.
content: WASHINGTON — Nets Coach Steve Nash gave a pained smile in the barren hallway leading to the court at Capital One Arena. The Nets were in the middle of an implosion, having lost nine straight games, soon to be 10. He was asked about his unequivocal statement just days before that James Harden, the Nets’ All-Star guard, wouldn’t be traded.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlotta Gall
title: Taliban Free 2 Westerners Working for U.N., Days After Quiet Detention
description: The issue of detentions and disappearances has put a new spotlight on the Taliban’s promises to improve their human rights record under the weight of international sanctions.
content: ISTANBUL — The Taliban on Friday released two Western citizens and two Afghan colleagues who had been working for the United Nations in Afghanistan, hours after the U.N. had announced that they had been held by the Taliban for several days in Afghanistan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: C.I.A. Is Collecting in Bulk Certain Data Affecting Americans, Senators Warn
description: A partly declassified letter from two senators, Ron Wyden and Martin Heinrich, does not say what the data is.
content: WASHINGTON — The Central Intelligence Agency has for years been collecting in bulk, without a warrant, some kind of data that can affect Americans’ privacy, according to a newly declassified letter by two senators.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Parker-Pope and Jin Yu Young
title: What to Know About the KF94 Mask
description: This high-quality mask, made in South Korea, is often described as more comfortable than other respirator masks. Here’s how to find the real thing.
content: Even as mask mandates begin to lift across the country, many people still need high-quality masks for air travel, shopping and visiting the doctor. One of the best options is the KF94 from South Korea.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Draper
title: Van der Poel breaks the world record in the men’s 10,000-meter speedskating.
description: His time was almost 14 seconds, about half a lap, faster than any other skater in the race.
content: Nils van der Poel broke his own world record Friday night en route to winning the men’s 10,000-meter speedskating race and picking up his second gold medal of the Beijing Olympics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Thomas
title: U.S. prime-time broadcast coverage includes snowboarding, biathlon and hockey.
description: Lindsey Jacobellis, the snowboard cross star, and Nick Baumgartner compete on one of two U.S. squads in the mixed team event.
content: The U.S. broadcast coverage of the 2022 Winter Games continues on Friday with medal events in snowboarding, hockey and Alpine and cross-country skiing. All times are Eastern.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Brooks
title: What the Beatles Tell Us About Fame
description: No matter how talented you are, you need champions.
content: Let’s say you’re a musician, artist or actor with dreams of making it big. How do you do that?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brett Berk
title: In Search of the Meaning of Life? Meet Me at the Monkey Bars.
description: Julian Shapiro-Barnum interviews kids for his social media sensation “Recess Therapy.”
content: Julian Shapiro-Barnum brims with creative energy, often scribbling ideas for new projects in his Moleskine the way others might add items to a shopping list. And though he graduated in 2021 from the B.F.A. acting program at Boston University, he said he’s never wanted fame.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane, Aishvarya Kavi and Zach Montague
title: On Capitol Hill, a Push to Unionize House Aides Gains Traction
description: Democrats have signed on to a resolution that would for the first time give House aides the same organizing protections other federal government employees enjoy.
content: WASHINGTON — More than 25 years after Congress first voted to give its employees the right to unionize, Democrats are making a fresh push to make it possible for House aides to bargain collectively, an uphill effort that has exposed the often difficult realities of working on Capitol Hill.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren McCarthy
title: Who is Valentino Guseli?
description: Valentino Guseli, a 16-year-old from Australia, began to make a name for himself when he broke the world record for the highest vertical last year at his first World Cup contest.
content: Valentino Guseli, a 16-year-old from Australia, began to make a name for himself when he broke the world record for the highest vertical last year at his first World Cup contest.

title: The Chinese men’s hockey team has an international cast.
description: Making its debut in the Winter Olympics, the team reached far and wide to cobble together a competitive roster.
content: The descendants of some of the many Chinese people who emigrated to North America in the 19th century are back in China, playing hockey for the host team at the Beijing Olympics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Alter
title: Shining a Spotlight on the Art of Translation
description: Jennifer Croft, who translates the Nobel Prize-winning Polish novelist Olga Tokarczuk, is leading a push for her peers and their work to receive more recognition.
content: When Jennifer Croft talks about translating the Polish novelist Olga Tokarczuk’s novel “Flights,” she sometimes affectionately refers to the book as “our love child.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: A speedskating rivalry between the Netherlands and Sweden heats up in Beijing.
description: Nils van der Poel of Sweden has won every distance race he entered this year.
content: Follow our latest coverage of the 2022 Winter Olympics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Acrostic
description: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon remind us of some famous choppers on a famous chopper.
content: ACROSTIC — Let this puzzle serve as a reminder that it’s not too late to order your chocolates and flowers for Presidents’ Day, which falls on Feb. 21 this year, a day before George Washington’s actual birthday. (He’ll be 290 years old.) As a committed non scholar of the founders, I have scant knowledge of Washington, mostly pertaining to the cherry tree and his wooden teeth, both of which are fallacies. Today’s passage concerns the teeth and their actual composition.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Love Letter: What is Black Love Today?
description: We gathered stories that illuminate how Black people live, and love, in this moment.
content: Last August, Modern Love and The New York Times’s Narrative Projects team invited readers and a few prominent writers to respond to the question: “What is Black love today?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden
title: Inspired by Canadian protests, thousands of French demonstrators converge on Paris.
description: The police have deployed over 7,000 officers around the city and have already issued a ban against the convoy.
content: Thousands of vehicles carrying demonstrators from around France were converging on Paris on Friday in a movement inspired by Canada’s trucker-led protests, despite warnings by French authorities that they would break up attempts to block the capital.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lindsay Crouse
title: ‘Queen Lucy’ Was a Basketball Superstar. How Will We Remember Her?
description: Ms. Harris knew that basketball wouldn’t bring her the rewards it offered her male counterparts, but she loved the game. And she loved being great at it.
content: The daughter of sharecroppers. The only Black basketball player on a college team she led to three national championships. The first woman to score a basket at the Olympics. So good she was the first (and only) woman officially drafted by the National Basketball Association.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margot Boyer-Dry
title: Will Rapid Grocery Delivery Change N.Y.C.? Look to Berlin.
description: In Germany’s capital, workers are striking, congestion is on the rise and the German bodega — the spätkauf — is under threat.
content: When he moved to a new apartment last fall, Garret MacAllen needed garbage bags, so he placed his first order through Gorillas, a rapid delivery service that had just arrived in New York. Since then, he has grown more reliant on the app, which promises groceries in minutes, delivering corner-store basics like milk and eggs alongside specialty items like gourmet frozen pizzas and artisanal chocolates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Shpigel
title: Aaron Rodgers Wins Fourth N.F.L. M.V.P. Award
description: He became the fifth player to win consecutive Most Valuable Player Awards and now trails only Peyton Manning on the career list. The Pro Football Hall of Fame also welcomed eight new members.
content: LOS ANGELES — Before Aaron Rodgers teed off this week at the 16th hole of a pro-am event in Arizona, an announcer introduced him as a three-time winner of the N.F.L.’s Most Valuable Player Award. Without hesitating, Rodgers flashed four fingers instead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Fuhrer
title: When Ski Ballet Pushed at the Porous Boundary Between Art and Sport
description: “We brought music to the mountains”: The rebel freestyle form born in the ’70s had a brief Olympic moment. Now it’s experiencing a renaissance online.
content: Recently, the official Olympics YouTube account posted a video both beautiful and strange. Skiers in flamboyant jumpsuits perform choreographed routines to music — flipping over their poles, gliding through complex spins, accenting transitions with jazzy flourishes of their arms. “HOW was this an Olympic sport?” the video’s title wonders.
source.name: The New York Times

title: U.S. intelligence says Putin has accelerated his timetable and could invade within days.
description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken said at a news conference in Melbourne on Friday that a Russian invasion could even occur before the Winter Olympics in Beijing end on Feb. 20.
content: The U.S. intelligence community has told the White House and American allies that there are signs that President Vladimir V. Putin has moved up his timetable and could launch an invasion of Ukraine within days, according three Western officials briefed on the discussions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron and Emma G. Fitzsimmons
title: New York could fire as many as 3,000 unvaccinated city workers on Friday.
description: New York City on Friday is expected to fire as many as 3,000 municipal workers who have refused to get coronavirus vaccines.
content: New York City on Friday is expected to fire as many as 3,000 municipal workers who have refused to get coronavirus vaccines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Keh
title: Why Are Russians in Beijing if Russia Is Banned for Doping?
description: A figure skating crisis raises new questions about the participation of Russian athletes while their country is banned from global sports after a doping scandal.
content: BEIJING — The figure skating competition at the 2022 Beijing Olympics was thrown into turmoil on Friday with the revelation that Kamila Valieva, the 15-year-old star of the Russian team and a favorite to win two golds, had tested positive for a banned substance during a competition before the Games.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Douglas Trumbull, Visual Effects Wizard, Dies at 79
description: His technical savvy was on display in films like “2001: A Space Odyssey,” “Star Trek: the Motion Picture,” “Close Encounters of the Third Kind” and “Blade Runner.”
content: Douglas Trumbull, an audacious visual effects wizard who created memorable moments in a series of blockbuster science-fiction films, including the hallucinogenic sequence in Stanley Kubrick’s “2001: A Space Odyssey” in which an astronaut in a pod hurtles through space, died on Monday at a hospital in Albany, N.Y. He was 79.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Bob Wall, Martial Arts Master Who Sparred With Bruce Lee, Dies at 82
description: He taught thousands of senseis how to run a dojo, all the while trading kicks onscreen with Lee and Chuck Norris.
content: Bob Wall, a martial arts master who with quick business wits and even fleeter fists propelled disciplines like karate, aikido and Brazilian jiu-jitsu into the American mainstream, along the way making friends and sharing the screen with the likes of Bruce Lee and Chuck Norris, died on Jan. 30 in Los Angeles. He was 82.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Wonking Out: Very Serious Folk Economics
description: Lessons from 2010’s debates for 2022.
content: A few days ago, Tressie McMillan Cottom published an insightful article in The Times about the power of “folk economics” — which she defined as “the very human impulse to describe complex economic processes in lay terms.” Her subject was the widespread enthusiasm for cryptocurrency, but her article sent me down memory lane, recalling the role folk economics has played in past policy debates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Vrentas
title: Once a Threat to the Season, Omicron Is Sitting Out the Super Bowl
description: As the Omicron coronavirus variant appears to run its course, infections in the N.F.L. are falling sharply. A change in testing policy may also play a role.
content: Less than two months ago, the Los Angeles Rams were going through what quarterback Matthew Stafford called “that tough couple weeks.” As the Omicron variant of the coronavirus swept across the country, more than 30 Rams players tested positive during the last three weeks of December. At one point, nearly all of them, including seven starters, were on the reserve/Covid-19 list at the same time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Friday Briefing
description: Russia closes in on Ukraine.
content: The Kremlin is tightening its military vise on Ukraine, as thousands of Russian troops yesterday began 10 days of exercises in Belarus. Ukraine also warned of upcoming Russian naval drills so extensive that they would block shipping lanes. Aside from Belarus, satellite images revealed deployments of Russian military equipment and troops in Crimea and western Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

title: In the Jewish Tradition, the Words We Choose Matter
description: Jews in America are wary and weary.
content: The Torah begins with the world being created by words. “Let there be” is the recurring refrain. God names each item — Light. Day. Night. Darkness. Earth. Sea. Heaven. From this emerges the concept that words can build or destroy.

author: By Kara Swisher
title: The Pandemic Culls the Big Tech Herd
description: Bigger is still better, as the largest tech firms keep gobbling up weakened rivals.
content: It feels like another turbulent time in tech, another paradigm shift, like what happened with the move to mobile. In this case, it is a move away from the internet as we know it (Web2) — a soft-touch regulatory environment — to what’s being called Web3, where actual guardrails might be erected.

author: By Lena Wilson
title: ‘The In Between’ Review: Love Never Dies
description: A teenage girl thinks that her dead boyfriend’s spirit is reaching out from the Great Beyond.
content: Like its foremother, “Twilight,” “The In Between” depicts a pedantic girl in a supernatural world who’s willing to die for her boyfriend. But where the “Twilight” films at least culminated in a decapitation or two, this feature, from the director Arie Posin and the “Serendipity” screenwriter Marc Klein, focuses solely on its fatal romance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Ezra Klein Show'
title: It’s Not Your Fault You Can’t Pay Attention. Here’s Why.
description: Johann Hari offers a surprising theory for why it’s so difficult to pay attention.
content: “The sensation of being alive in the early 21st century consisted of the sense that our ability to pay attention — to focus — was cracking and breaking,” writes Johann Hari in his new book, “Stolen Focus.” Later he says, “It felt like our civilization had been covered with itching powder and we spent our time twitching and twerking our minds, unable to simply give attention to things that matter.”

author: By Patricia Mazzei
title: How a Tawdry Steakhouse Melee Transfixed Miami Politics
description: A city commissioner was dining at Morton’s. A lobbyist came up with a beef that wasn’t about lunch. Everyone called the police. The incident has dominated Miami’s political chatter for days.
content: CORAL GABLES, Fla. — Every so often, a petty political episode consumes Miami, its piquant details transfixing the city for days. Like the one that began this week at Morton’s Steakhouse during a late lunch, when a lobbyist happened upon a city commissioner.

content: The teenage Russian phenom glided across the ice and thrust herself into figure skating history. Leaping and spinning at high speed on Monday night, Kamila Valieva became the first female figure skater to complete a quad — a jump with four rotations — at the Olympics.

title: A Spiritual, Dangerous Quest in the Himalayas
description: Harley Rustad talks about “Lost in the Valley of Death,” and Jessamine Chan discusses “The School for Good Mothers.”
content: Harley Rustad’s new book, “Lost in the Valley of Death,” is about an American adventurer named Justin Alexander Shetler, who went on a quest in the Himalayas that ended in his disappearance. One of Shetler’s heroes was Christopher McCandless, whose story was told in Jon Krakauer’s “Into the Wild.” On this week’s podcast, Rustad discusses Shetler’s life, including his use of social media and how that dovetailed — and didn’t — with his spiritual journey.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Branch
title: Shaun White Finds the Glory in Falling Short
description: Trying for one last Olympic medal, the 35-year-old snowboarding champion was surpassed by his heirs apparent. That, in itself, was enough.
content: ZHANGJIAKOU, China — It all came to an end here, on a tilted chute of ice on an unnamed mountain in China, and the only surprise was that 35-year-old Shaun White did not have one more trick in him. He had made a career of such things.
source.name: The New York Times

description: Jakara Anthony won the women’s moguls event in freestyle skiing, while Jaclyn Narracott leads going into the women’s skeleton final.

author: By Suhasini Raj and Emily Schmall
title: No Hijabs for Now, Indian Court Tells Muslim Students
description: In a dispute that’s become a flash point over minority rights, students are told to avoid religious garments of all kinds, pending a ruling on whether schools can ban head scarves.
content: UDUPI, India — An Indian court has said that students in the southern state of Karnataka should stop wearing religious garments in class until it makes a final ruling on whether a school there can ban Muslim head scarves, an issue that has stoked weeks of protests and violence and led the authorities to close schools across the state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Seth Colter Walls
title: For Three Avant-Garde Musicians, It’s Time for Pop
description: New albums by Jeff Tobias, Joseph White and Dave Ruder all have some experimental edges. But they also have catchy hooks.
content: In his recent documentary about the Velvet Underground, Todd Haynes depicted both poles of that group’s creativity. There were moments featuring collaborations with experimental composers like La Monte Young and Tony Conrad, but also passages of fairly pure pop bliss.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bakalar
title: A 1,500-Year-Old Riddle Solved: Yes, It Was a Terra-Cotta Porta-Potty
description: The proof was in the, er, concretion.
content: Archaeologists working at ancient Roman sites commonly find ceramics, but it is not always easy to know what these objects were used for. Wine storage? Food transportation? Tableware? Or were they purely decorative? Experts often disagree. But now a team of researchers working at a Roman site that dates from about 450 to 500 A.D. have definitive proof that one of the pots they found was a portable toilet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ginia Bellafante
title: They Criticized the N.Y.P.D. It Cost Them Their Jobs.
description: In the aftermath of two police funerals, three New Yorkers — two teachers and an actress — were fired after social media posts. Are we entering a new phase of intolerance?
content: In the shadow of the Verrazzano-Narrows Bridge, Fontbonne Hall Academy in Brooklyn has not been hit by the forces of cultural change quite as bluntly as so many other private schools, which have spent the past few years embracing increasingly progressive values. Founded in 1937 by the Congregation of the Sisters of St. Joseph, an order devoted to the goal of fostering “love, unity and reconciliation,” the girls’ school professes a commitment to “restorative justice.” But when it had the opportunity to put that principle into practice last week, it chose a less forgiving path.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Makiko Inoue
title: A broadcaster’s lineup creates a halfpipe cliffhanger in Japan.
description: Ayumu Hirano was in position to win heading into his final run, and his fans were glued to the television. Then the signal dropped.
content: It was Ayumu Hirano’s last ride, and the final run of the men’s halfpipe finals at the Beijing Olympics on Friday. Shaun White, the American snowboarder competing in his last Olympic Games, had already fallen, leaving a spot for his successor on the top step of the medals podium.

title: An Arizona county turned down $1.9 million in Covid relief. This is why.

content: The $1.9 million in pandemic aid would have gone a long way in Cochise County, Ariz., a rural borderland where a winter of infections swamped hospitals. There was money for tracking cases. Testing in remote ranching towns. Funds fortifying the county’s strained health department.

author: By Eshe Nelson
title: Omicron stalled Britain’s economic recovery in December.
description: Still, the impact was milder than feared, and the country’s economy grew 7.5 percent in 2021, the fastest pace in eight decades.
content: The sudden emergence of the fast-spreading Omicron variant of the coronavirus in Britain late last year stalled the country’s economic recovery, data confirmed on Friday, though the impact was milder than expected.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Spelling Bee Forum

title: Richard Christiansen, Influential Chicago Theater Critic, Dies at 90
description: His reviews for The Chicago Tribune, and his encouragement of the drama crowd, helped make Chicago one of the country’s leading theater cities.
content: In 1970, as Americans were preparing to mark the first Earth Day, Richard Christiansen, still relatively early in what became a storied career of writing about theater in Chicago, seized the moment to argue that the arts deserved just as much attention as the environment but were unlikely to receive it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hanya Yanagihara
title: Finding Comfort in Trials and Triumphs Past

content: Next month, the Covid-19 pandemic enters its third year. Many of us thought that by now we’d be looking at the virus in retrospect, instead of living in a kind of perpetually deferred future tense.

title: In Fourth Title Defense, Israel Adesanya Will Face a Familiar Foe

content: A diamond stud glittered in Israel Adesanya’s left ear, while the right sleeve on his beige suede jacket rode up to expose a gleaming gold watch. The timepiece matched the shiny plates on the front of the black leather title belt that Adesanya had placed on the dais for the fight week news conference.

title: Medina Spirit May Have Died of a Heart Attack, a Necropsy Finds
description: But the report was inconclusive. The colt, who tested positive for a banned substance last May after winning the Kentucky Derby, collapsed after a workout in December.
content: Medina Spirit, the race horse whose victory in the 2021 Kentucky Derby had been called into question by a failed post-race drug test, may have died of a heart attack but a necropsy report was inconclusive, according to California regulators on Friday. Hair, blood and urine samples showed no evidence of doping.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua M. Bernstein
title: More Brew and Less Buzz, With Low-Alcohol Beers

content: One summer day in 2018, Sean Boisson was washing his car in Sonoma, Calif., when a bubbly little epiphany arrived. He asked his younger sister, Brittany Rossi, who was helping, if she wanted a second beer — a domestic lager low in alcohol, but not quite low enough. “She was like: ‘No, I’ve got to drive. I can only have one,’” Mr. Boisson recalled.

content: WASHINGTON — President Biden on Thursday warned Americans to leave Ukraine, saying that U.S. troops would not be dispatched to retrieve them should Russia invade.

title: The Auto Industry’s Trucker Problem
description: A blockade of key trade routes between the U.S. and Canada is roiling car makers’ businesses.
content: Thousands of truckers in Canada, protesting vaccine mandates and other restrictions, have blocked traffic at a number of key border crossings with the U.S. in the past few days. This has clogged some of the auto industry’s main routes to get car parts into and out of the U.S. The Ambassador Bridge, which connects Windsor and Detroit, carries roughly a quarter of the trade between Canada and the U.S., and a third of the cargo that uses the bridge is related to the auto industry.

title: A Dance to the Music of Time and T.S. Eliot

content: In its beginning is its end. In its end is its beginning. Those tail-eating lines, paraphrased from “Four Quartets,” the poem by T.S. Eliot, tell you the outer shape of “Four Quartets,” the much-acclaimed dance by Pam Tanowitz that had its New York City debut at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

content: AL BARSHA, Egypt — When the star of “Feathers,” the most talked about — and critically acclaimed — Egyptian movie of the past year, showed up to shoot her first scenes, she had never acted before. She could not even read her lines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Snyder
title: In Mexico, Ornately Painted Churches Enshrine Years of Indigenous Resilience
description: As Michoacán’s centuries-old chapels undergo restorations, the buildings raise new questions about how architectural conservation should work — and whom such projects are really for.
content: FOR CENTURIES, THE first thing that residents of the Mexican village of Nurio saw when they walked through the heavy wooden doors of their adobe-plastered church was an orchestra of angels. Painted on pine panels mounted in an arch beneath the choir, the images were likely completed in the mid-1600s, less than 150 years after the first Franciscan missionaries arrived here in the Meseta Purépecha, or Tarascan Plateau, a highland region in the Michoacán state named for the Indigenous community that resides there. Set in pearlescent medallions against a blue-green field coiled with gold and crimson filigree, the angels held harps, guitars and violins in their hands, their Baroque lips curved into smiles — an image of heaven filled with music, order and joy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miguel Salazar
title: New in Paperback: ‘The Vanishing Half’ and ‘Tangled Up in Blue’
description: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.
content: THE VANISHING HALF, by Brit Bennett. (Riverhead, 400 pp., $18.) Bennett’s novel, one of the Book Review’s 10 Best Books of 2020, follows the diverging lives of two mixed-race women from Louisiana as they try to find their footing in America during the late 20th century. Our reviewer, Ayana Mathis, called it “a brave foray into vast and difficult terrain” that “raises thorny questions about the cost of blackness.”

content: OTTAWA — After weeks of treading lightly around the protests paralyzing much of Canada’s economy, federal, provincial and local officials adopted a markedly tougher approach on Friday, threatening protesters with arrests and heavy fines, and obtaining a court order to halt the blockade of a major route to the United States.

Putin of Russia is flexing his military and diplomatic muscle in a tense standoff with the West over Ukraine, projecting power and occasional menace in his pursuit of global influence. But the recent abduction of a 52-year-old diabetic woman in central Russia  has made clear that Mr. Putin still has vexing challenges in his own backyard that require a skillful political juggling act.

content: Thirty-eight of Harvard’s leading lights, people who are among the most accomplished and admired intellectuals in the world, last week signed an open letter expressing their concern that a colleague, the renowned anthropologist John Comaroff, had been punished for violating the school’s sexual and professional conduct policies. Among them was the African-American studies professor, critic and filmmaker Henry Louis Gates Jr., the historian and New Yorker writer Jill Lepore, the medical anthropologist and physician Paul Farmer and the postcolonial theorist Homi K. Bhabha.

author: By Sabrina Imbler
title: The Slippery Science of Skeleton
description: Researchers are still figuring out how to enable athletes in the face-first Olympic sled race to go even faster.
content: Many Winter Olympic sports have ancient origins, dating to times when humans invented new ways of getting around in the harsh, white wilderness. Skiing may have first emerged 10,000 years ago in Altay, China, and the Indigenous Sámi word for skiing (“čuoigat”) is estimated to be 6,000 to 8,000 years old. Thousands of years ago in Northern Europe, people strapped animal bones to their feet to skate around on ice. And the First Peoples in Canada used toboggans to transport goods.
